quoteFirst: All the rules of the establishment are printed and posted in your bedroom; you have to submit to them. No question to ask--you know everything. Henceforth you will have to be hungry from 7 to 9 A.M.; from 1 to 3 P.M.; from
quoteLast: The slightest infringement of the routine would stop the wheel, so don't ask if you could have a meal at four o'clock; you would be taken for a lunatic, or a crank (as they call it in America).
title: A Frenchman in America: Recollections of Men and Things
author: O'Rell, Max, 1848-1903

quoteFirst: This extraordinary-looking turn-out continued its headlong course over bog-roads and through rough country lanes, to the astonishment of the inhabitants, till the lame farmer's house was reached. He was carefully lifted into the carriage, conveyed to the polling-place, and recorded his vote at
quoteLast: , with just six minutes to spare before the poll closed. As it turned out I won the seat by fifty-six votes, so this rapid journey was really superfluous, but we all thought that it would be a much closer thing.
title: Here, There and Everywhere
author: Hamilton, Frederic, Lord, 1856-1928

quoteFirst: The “dog-watch” is a nautical term distinguishing two watches of two hours each, from 4 to 6 P. M. and
title:
The Wonder Book of Knowledge
The Marvels of Modern Industry and Invention, the Interesting Stories of Common Things, the Mysterious Processes of Nature Simply Explained
author: Hill, Henry Chase [Editor]

quoteFirst: Here, by a happy coincidence, there was a sturdy hammering heard at the front door, and Andrew Marvell was ushered in, "I am out of my due time," said he, "for it is not yet gone six,"--(
quoteLast: being Milton's best time for receiving visitors). "Yet to so old an offender as myself, John, I know thou wilt make an exception.
title: A Day with John Milton
author: Byron, May, 1861-1936; Milton, John, 1608-1674 [Contributor]; Meteyard, Sidney, 1868-1947 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , p. m., angular distance from Sirius, 74° 48′ 20″; length of tail, 24° 16′.

quoteFirst: 30 P. M. Roll call at 8 P. M. Tuesday and Friday evenings a recitation in tactics from
quoteLast: A detail of one man from each company and one corporal from the regiment for policing camp. A pass to two men from each company each day, to visit the city or call upon friends, time of leaving and returning to be written on pass.
title: Diary of an Enlisted Man
author: Van Alstyne, Lawrence, 1839-1923

quoteFirst: Twice a day, if the captain gave the order, he had to open this room, to serve out provisions to the cooks of the messes, weighing every atom with scrupulous care. The times of serving out were generally from seven to nine in the morning, and from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: . To encourage him to be careful and thrifty he received a bonus on the provisions remaining with him at the end of a cruise, when the ship was paid off. He also received 10 per cent. on all sums paid to the crew “for savings of provisions.
title: Sea life in Nelson's time
author: Masefield, John, 1878-1967

quoteFirst: "Well, the matter can be arranged without depriving myself of your services," said M. Vulfran; "there is a very good teacher here and I will ask her to give you lessons from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: s. She is a very nice woman; there are only two things against her; they are her height and her name; she is taller than I am, and her shoulders are much broader than mine. Her name is Mademoiselle Belhomme. She is indeed a _bel homme_, for although she is only forty her shoulders and figure are more massive than any man's I know ...
title:
Nobody's Girl
(En Famille)
author: Malot, Hector, 1830-1907; Gooch, Thelma, 1895-1973 [Illustrator]; Crewe-Jones, Florence, 1876-1940 [Translator]

quoteFirst: On the first day the examination of surveyors is continued for four hours, viz. from 2 to 4 and
quoteLast: and consists of written papers only. Inspectors of nuisances have two hours’ written examination on the first day, viz. from 4 to 6 P.M. On the second day the examination for both classes commences at 11 A.M., and is _vivâ voce_; with one or more questions to be answered in writing if deemed necessary.
title: The Municipal and Sanitary Engineer's Handbook
author: Boulnois, H. Percy (Henry Percy), 1846-1927

quoteFirst: The second dog-watch, from
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening

quoteFirst: Very soon Pat Francis dropped off De Molay Four, slowing at Elcho, ran straight to the operator for his order, signed it and at once Order 79 was throbbing back to young Giddings at Medicine Bend. It was precisely
quoteLast: when Giddings gave back the Complete and at 7.55 Elcho reported Special 326, "out," all just like clockwork. What a head Martin Duffy has, thought young Giddings--and behold! all the complicated everlasting headwork of the trick and the day, and of the West End and its honor, was now up to the signature of Third Eighty at Rat River.
title: Held for Orders: Being Stories of Railroad Life
author: Spearman, Frank H. (Frank Hamilton), 1859-1937; Hambidge, Jay, 1867-1924 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: “Watch and watch” is the rule on small sailing-vessels: four hours on and four hours off, day and night, except for the “dog watches,” four to six and
quoteTime: six to eight in the evening
quoteLast: , which create a daily shift in order that each man may be on watch at a different time on successive days. Always provided, of course, that the ship has any watches at all! I _have_ sailed in a Pacific schooner where the crew spent most of their time playing the accordion and the Jew’s harp, and slept peacefully all night.
title: In the Strange South Seas
author: Grimshaw, Beatrice, 1871-1953

quoteFirst: On the first day the examination of surveyors is continued for four hours, viz. from 2 to 4 and
quoteLast: and consists of written papers only. Inspectors of nuisances have two hours’ written examination on the first day, viz. from 4 to 6 P.M. On the second day the examination for both classes commences at 11 A.M., and is _vivâ voce_; with one or more questions to be answered in writing if deemed necessary.
